newsitem.title: CANADA: Bombardier unit hopeful on contract talks.
newsitem.headline: Bombardier unit hopeful on contract talks.

text.p: Bombardier Inc's de Havilland unit is hopeful that contract talks with its 3,800 unionized workers will conclude successfully before the Monday morning strike deadline, a company official said on Friday.
"There has been considerable progress made, but there are still several sub-issues that have got to be worked through," Bombardier Aerospace group spokesman Colin Fisher told Reuters.
"It is planned that talks will continue throughout the weekend and we're optimistic about reaching a settlement," he said.

The Canadian Auto Workers, which represents 3,800 of the 6,326 workers at Toronto-based de Havilland, said on Friday that it received a new contract offer from the company. The CAW set a strike deadline for 1000 EDT on Monday if the two sides failed to reach an agreement.
CAW spokeswoman Jane Armstrong said the new contract offer was a request that the union revise its position, but the union also expected to continue bargaining through the weekend.
"We expect bargaining around-the-clock through the weekend," she told Reuters.

Fisher declined to specify the outstanding issues, but Armstrong said the union was opposed to the company's demand that workers accept a five-year contract. The union also wanted improved wage and pension compensation, she said.
The Downsview plant makes the de Havilland Dash-8 family of turboprop regional aircraft and is responsible for the final assembly of the new Bombardier Global Express long-range business jet.
Fisher said that de Havilland was optimistic there would be a settlement before the Monday deadline, but in case of a strike, the plant would keep operating with non-unionized employees.

Armstrong said the CAW settled contracts without a strike at de Havilland only once in eight rounds of bargaining over the years. The CAW went on a one-week strike at de Havilland in 1994, about a year after Montreal-based Bombardier acquired control of the company from Boeing Co, she said.
